did.unittitle:
Frank Baker papers 1641-2002 and undated
bulk 1740-1995
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Scholar, editor, collector, and Duke University faculty member specializing in the history of English and American Methodist history, and the life and career of minister John Wesley. Collection documents the professional career and life of Frank Baker, historian of Methodism and particularly of the founder and Methodist minister John Wesley. Materials are arranged in the following series: Baker Collections Files; Correspondence; Libraries and Archives; Ministry; Personal Files; Printed Materials; Professional Service; Scrapbooks and Albums; Subject Files; Teaching Materials; and Writings and Research. Topics covered include: the history of the Baker book and manuscript collections in the Duke University libraries; the history and development of Methodism and of the Wesley family; the Church of England; the Methodist Church in England, the U.S., and other countries; the development of academic research on Methodist history; music and hymnology; and material on the Wesley Works Series, a publishing project headed by Baker. There are abundant research materials on notable individuals associated with Methodism such as Charles Wesley and many other Wesley family members, William Grimshaw, and Francis Asbury. Printed material abounds, and includes many maps, articles, clippings and newspapers, pamphlets, and religious music.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
In addition, original audiovisual materials are closed to patron use. Research Services staff need to produce use copies before contents can be accessed.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note

chronitem.event: Born in Hull, Yorkshire, England, to Frank and Annie Elizabeth Baker
B.A., University College of Hull, (external degree of University of London; honors)
B.D., University of Manchester, England
Minister of British Methodist Church in seven circuits, including Warminster, Westbury, Keighley, Bury, Ramsbottom, Mansfield, Cleethorpes, and Hull North
Won Eayrs Essay Prize for "John Wesley's Christian Library," to which point he dated his interest in historical research
Married Ellen Eliza Levitt
Ordained as a Methodist Minister
Published A Charge to Keep: An Introduction to the People Called Methodists
Publication of Charles Wesley as Revealed by His Letters
Published The Methodist Pilgrim in England
Published "The Rev. William Grimshaw (1708-1763) and the Eighteenth-Century Revival of Religion in England," thesis
Publication of Methodism and the Love Feast
Professor of English Church History in Department of Religion and in Divinity School, Duke University

eventgrp.event: Appointed as Associate Editor and Archivist on the Wesley Works Editorial Board
Duke purchased core of Frank Baker’s personal rare book and manuscript collection on the history of Methodism, later named the Frank Baker Collection of Wesleyana and British Methodism

chronitem.event: Edited Representative Verse of Charles Wesley
Published William Grimshaw, 1708-1763
Compiled A Union Catalogue of Publications of John and Charles Wesley
Editor-in-Chief of the Wesley Works Editorial Project
Published John Wesley and the Church of England
Published From Wesley to Asbury: Studies in Early American Methodism
Received Emeritus Status at Duke University
Edited Letters I and II (the Correspondence of John Wesley)
Introductor of The Heart of True Spirituality: John Wesley's Own Choice
Served on editorial board for A History of the Methodist Church in Great Britain
Died in Durham, N.C.

bioghist.p: Frank Baker also wrote over 200 articles, essays, and published papers, including 80 entries for the Encyclopedia of World Methodism

Memberships: World Methodist Historical Society (executive, 1970-1999?), Wesley Historical Society, Royal Historical Society, International Methodist Historical Society (joint secretary, 1947-1960), American Society of Church History.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Frank Baker Papers date from 1641 through 2002, with the majority of the materials dating from the 1800s to the 1990s. The collection houses correspondence, articles, pamphlets, extensive subject and research files, clippings, publicity, a few audio recordings and microfilm, and other materials documenting the professional career and life of Frank Baker, historian of Methodism and particularly of the life and career of minister John Wesley, considered the founder of British Methodism. The collection is arranged in the following series: Audiovisual Materials, Baker Collections Files; Correspondence; Libraries and Archives; Ministry; Personal Files; Printed Material; Professional Service; Scrapbooks and Albums; Subject Files; Teaching Materials; and Writings and Research. Many of the series are divided into subseries, and two are also followed by an Oversize Materials subseries. Note that early dates usually represent reproductions, not originals, although the collection does house some original research materials.

Topics covered by the materials in the collection include: the history and development of Methodism and of the Wesley family; the history of the Church of England, and the Methodist Church in England, the U.S., and other countries; the development of academic research on Methodism and its publications; the history of the Baker book and manuscript collections in the Duke University Libraries; music and hymnology; and the development of the Wesley Works Series, a publishing project headed by Baker. There are abundant research materials on notable individuals associated with Methodism such as John and Charles Wesley, many other Wesley family members, and others such as William Grimshaw and Francis Asbury.

The largest series is the Subject Files (122 boxes), research files assembled by Baker on approximately 1500 topics related to the Wesley family and the history of Methodism and the Methodist Church. Another large series is Writings and Research (48 boxes), containing files of research notes, correspondence, print materials, and publicity related to each of Baker's published works. There are also many student writings in the collection and other materials related to Baker's teaching. Among the Personal Files are biographical files on Frank Baker; awards and honors; travel-related items, and two portrait photographs of Baker's parents. Baker's personal hobbies are reflected in the stamp collecting materials and a group of Victorian-era monogram and crest albums and "libri amicorum," or friendship albums that round out the collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p:
The Frank Baker Papers form part of a larger group of collections gathered by Baker during his long career as a collector and scholar. These collections, plus others housed in both the Rubenstein Library and the Duke Divinity School Library, contain extensive materials related to this collection. Rubenstein Library collections are listed first, followed by Divinity School collections.
Frank Baker Collection of Wesleyana and British Methodism (printed materials division). Holds hundreds of editions of John Wesley's sermons, hymns, journals, and editorial works, plus such organizational materials as minutes of the Methodist Conferences. These materials can be searched in the online catalog by individual title, by genre, or by using the full name of the collection in the author field: Frank Baker Collection of Wesleyana and British Methodism.
Frank Baker Collection of Wesleyana and British Methodism, 1632-1996 and undated. Most directly relate to the Letters Series of the WWA. The Wesley Family Series holds a number of John Wesley's autograph letters; numerous incoming letters can also be found here and in certain subseries of the Correspondence Series. Most of these letters date after 1755 and thus have not appeared in the two volumes of letters published to date.
Wesley Works Archive, 1676-1996 and undated, bulk 1724-1791, 1960-1996
. Working papers of the Wesley Works Editorial Project (WWEP), as gathered by Frank Baker during his years as the WWEP's General Editor, Textual Editor, and main bibliographer.
Wesley holograph letters also appear in two small sub-collections of the Wesleyana manuscripts, the
Sarah Crosby Papers, 1760-1804
and the
Perronet Family Papers, 1752-1855
Wesley autograph letters are also contained in two small non-Baker collections in the Rubenstein Library, the Wesley Family Papers, 1726-1889
[catalog record
; and the
G. (George) Story Papers, 1738-1818
The Frank Baker Microfilm Collection (Divinity Library) houses hundreds of microfilms from archives all over the world, collected at Baker's request from the 1960s-1980s. These microfilm thousands of images of Wesley manuscripts and printed materials used by the WWEP to gather as many as possible of the approximately 4000 editions of Wesley's publications to appear during his lifetime. Inquire at the Divinity Library Reference Desk.
The Frank Baker Photocopies Collection (Divinity Library) contains photocopies of several hundred of the rare monographs housed in the Rubenstein Library. These were often Baker's working copies of books he had already sold or given to the library, and are similar though not identical to the many photocopies in the WWA.
Duke Divinity School: Center for Studies in the Wesleyan Tradition
. Contains numerous original and digitized texts on Wesleyan and Methodist studies, as well as links to many other archival sources on the Web. A sub-page of this site serves as the online home of the
Wesley Works Editorial Project.
In addition to this general list, other related materials in the Duke Libraries are cited in certain series notes. Inquire at the Divinity Library Reference Desk.

separatedmaterial.head: Materials Cataloged Separately
separatedmaterial.p: The following books, offprints, pamphlets, and serial issues were removed from the collection and cataloged separately. Some titles are cataloged as part of the Frank Baker Collection of Wesleyana and British Methodism, others as gifts of Frank Baker for various branch libraries. All can be located by searching the Duke University Libraries online catalog. Arranged in two lists: Works by Frank Baker and Works by Other Authors.

scopecontent.p: Contains four reels of microfilm, two audio reels, and two cassette tapes. The microfilms were originally part of Baker's research materials, and contain many Methodist tracts, essays, verses, letters, and other short works dating from 1738-1789, according to library notes found with the reels.

did.unittitle: Baker Collections Files Series, 1955-2001 and undated

scopecontent.p: Baker's personal files documenting the history of his book and manuscript collections at Duke University libraries. Consists mainly of correspondence with Duke staff and faculty, inventories and accessions, appraisals of the collection, and publicity materials. Organized alphabetically by category.

Materials about the history of the Baker collections at Duke, including: addresses and exhibits honoring Frank Baker, chiefly from the 1980s; several published and unpublished articles by Baker and other authors about different aspects of the collections; and clippings and other publicity. Arranged alphabetically by author, speaker, or topic.

Baker's extensive inventories of the various portions of the original 1961 purchase, with many subsequent cataloging notes appended over the years; containing over 7000 items, these lists probably remain the fullest inventory of the printed materials in any single place, including the online catalog.
Arranged in reverse chronological order. Folder 9 contains Baker's original list of materials sold to the library circa 1960.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence prior to 1960, when Baker still lived in England, may be particularly of note to researchers interested in the provenance of materials in the various Baker collections at Duke. These letters often refer to his attempts to discover and acquire Wesleyan and Methodist research materials in the possession of private individuals, professional dealers, churches, local historical societies, and other organizations. The content of folders covering this period may range from itemized receipts to lengthy discussions and evaluations of the subject matter and authenticity of materials. Arranged chronologically to the year level.

scopecontent.p: Personal papers of Frank Baker (FB), including artwork, ephemera and memorabilia, financial papers and travel-related material. Arranged alphabetically by category. The 1920s Primitive Methodist materials housed under "Awards, certificates, and diplomas" constitute fairly late documents in the history of the church, prior to unification of the Methodist Church in 1932.

scopecontent.p: Honors awarded to Baker throughout his life, ranging from a Primitive Methodist Sunday School Scripture Examination Second Prize in the early 1920s to an honorary Doctor of Divinity degree presented by Asbury Theological Seminary in 1983. Also included here are various church and Sunday school certificates awarded to his wife and children, mainly from the 1950s. Oversize materials (folders 6-8) include secondary school and undergraduate awards and diplomas for Frank Baker; Primitive Methodist Teacher Training School certificates for Ellen Levitt and Frank Baker, 1920s; honorary citizen of Tennessee award for Frank Baker.

scopecontent.p: Small group of albums and scrapbooks from England, chiefly Victorian-era, collected by Frank Baker. They do not seem to have any particular association with or focus on Methodism; his interest in certain pieces may stem in part from his own English origins. One genre of albums contain collections of pasted-in stamps, crests, monograms, and other emblems, while another group takes the form of friendship albums, also known as "libri amicorum," containing inscriptions, cards, writings, and sketches from friends. These house an assortment of memorabilia, ephemera, original and copied writings, and fine sketches and drawings. Two seem to have their origins in Yorkshire, where Baker was born. A few have small photographs laid in or mounted. Bound in leather or board covered with paper, some with gilt tooling. Height given in centimeters.
Similar friendship albums can be found in the Rubenstein Library's Jantz Collection of Autograph Albums, as well as cataloged individually in the Duke Libraries catalog.

did.unittitle: Album: ephemera and stamps, 1865-1868 and undated

scopecontent.p: Small album, originally bought from a Bayswater bookseller, unknown owner. Contains over a dozen pasted-in colorful Christmas-season cards, many stamps in the form of arms, monograms, and crests, cards, and a few pressed plants. There are a few handwritten explanatory notes accompanying the crests and monograms. Some of the monograms are from Russia, with Cyrillic characters. Includes a few handwritten notes with dates of travel - India, 1868, and Mt. Sinai, 1865, with a pencil sketch of the latter with water and a boat in the foreground. There is also one tiny photograph of a man, possibly the owner.

did.unittitle: Album: stamps, crests, and monograms, after 1897

scopecontent.p: Anonymous album bound in stamped cloth on boards containing stamps with intricate and colorful arms, monograms, crests, and other cut-out emblems. Symbols represent royalty, nobility, military units, hotels, ships, English cities, clubs, schools, and commercial enterprises such as banks and insurance agencies. Last pages contain many advertisements from the coin and stamp dealers (the Lincolns, London) who sold this particular model of collector's album; latest date on the stamps advertised for sale is 1897.

Album sold by Marcus Ward & Co., owned by a Percival B. Walker (inscription on inside cover), housing colorful and intricate stamps of arms, monograms, crests, and other symbols. Symbols represent royalty, nobility, military units, hotels, ships, English cities, clubs, schools, and commercial enterprises. A stamp mentions the late Prince Albert, leading to the dating of the album. Bound in leather with gilt edges and stamping.

accessrestrict.p: [Attention: May need conservation prior to access. Please consult with Research Services staff before coming to use this material.]

scopecontent.p: Friendship album according to an inside cover inscription belonging to "A. Mabel Hall" of Blackthorn House, Bacup, Lancashire, England. An Annie Mabel Hall of Mytholme House, Waterfoot (Lancashire), was married in 1918 to Nicholas Tomlinson; the bride's father was cotton manufacturer Horace Hall. Entries includes pen and ink sketches of animals, people, and flowers, as well as poems, aphorisms, and other inscriptions, almost all dated, by men and women chiefly from Lancashire; they may have been the album owner's school friends. Two individuals added "Lowther College" to their names, which was a private school in Lancashire for girls.

Signed on first page with the name Martha Skelton. Bound with leather and marbled paper with gilt edges. Earliest date is accompanied by place name "The Elms," but there is no other location indicating residence of creator. Contents consist of inscriptions from friends; long poems and essays on themes such as love, heroism, death, and spirituality; valentine cards; original, fine sketches of locales and botanical drawings in color by Skelton and others; advertising leaflets; cards with caricatures, cartoons, and illustrations of individuals and scenes, including a colored engraving of "The Wooly-Headed Boy" from Knaresboro, a color drawing titled "Byron Contemplating the Ruins of Rome", and a silhouette of Napoleon; and memorabilia, including pressed plants from historical sites, chiefly in England. There are many loose items, but others are mounted on the pages. Missing pages 1-11.

Friendship album, bound in calf with gilt edges and tooling, with the name Mary Slade on first page, resident most likely in England. Chiefly long entries consisting of copies of poems and writings as well as original writings on topics such as impermanence, heroism, and spirituality; interspersed with original, well-executed drawings, small watercolors, and sketches of locales in England and in Europe, most without captions, rural characters such as "Cottage Girl," and birds and plants. A little less than half of the album is blank.

Friendship album, owner unknown, covered with worn marbled paper on boards. Place names (Almondbury, Poole, Horbury, Overton) center around West Yorkshire. The name David Haigh appears several times, with a letter laid in written by him while at the Overton School, to his parents, Dec. 1844. Chiefly page-length entries consisting of copies of poems by such authors as Shelley, and writings such as Rob Roy as well as original writings on topics such as the home chapel, spirituality, death, love, and valor. Includes one poem titled "African Chief," describing the noble captive in chains. Entries are interspersed with pasted-in engravings of castles and ruins, along with several very small mounted late 19th and early 20th century photographic portraits, one of David Haigh, and a photographic greeting card from the Anthony family, Almondbury/Poole. There is also a pressed leaf from the "Cowthorpe Oak," North Yorkshire, and bluebells from Waterloo battle site.

scopecontent.p: The largest series of the collection, containing Baker's research on some 1500 persons and topics related to the Wesley family and the history of Methodism. Note: early dates sometimes represent content, but there are also original documents. Materials include manuscript and print items; Baker's notes, including his typed and handwritten transcriptions of original documents; and Baker's correspondence with a wide variety of scholars, church officials, and rare book and manuscript dealers. Arranged in four subseries: two Alphabetical Subjects sequences, the Wesley Family Files, and the Card Files.

scopecontent.p: Folders 1-2 contain general research materials on Methodism in Germany. Folders 3-7 contain correspondence, photographs, and writings regarding the Baker family's acquaintance and ongoing relationship with a group of German prisoners-of-war, who were held at Camp Norton when the Bakers lived in Warsop, England, circa 1947. Additional background information about these events can be found in a 2002 letter from the Bakers' daughter Enid Hickingbotham, filed in the correspondence folder here, and in the undated address by Nellie Baker, "Make Us Builders of Peace." The folders also include two music manuscripts by Heinrich Heun from 1947 and 1948, and an article by Ilsabe Halves, Wir Beide Hand in Hand, 1995

scopecontent.p: Short biographies, autobiographies, memoirs, and anecdotes of approximately 100 people, many of them important to or representative of 18th-and 19th-century British Methodism or of English history and culture in general. Extracted and compiled by Baker from a variety of printed sources. Many individuals represented in these biographies may also appear elsewhere in the Subject Files.

Contents: Dr. Samuel Annesley; Joseph Barker; Edward Baines; Richard Baxter; Mary Brett; Emily Bronte; Jabez Bunting; John Bunyan; Elizabeth Burdsall; John Nelson; Cardinal Newman; Adam Clarke; George Clarke; Rev. Joseph Cockin; Samuel Taylor Coleridge; R. Costerdine; Joseph Cownley; Rev. John Crosse; Rev. Spedding Curwen; Samuel Drew; Christmas Evans; and Thomas Gandy.

Contents (continued from previous box): William Geden; Elizabeth Gellatly; Hugh Gilmore; Thomas Goldthorpe; Thomas Haigh; Thomas Hanby; Elizabeth Hannam; John Harrap; Jane Vizell Hazell; Samuel Hick; John Hickling; Rev. Thomas Hartwell Horne; John Jackson; Rev. W. Jay; William Johnson; Matthias Joyce; William Keer; Simon Kilham; Rev. Joel Abraham Knight; Thomas Lee; John Leifchild; Rev. G. C. Maitland; Johnathon Maskew; John Mason; Ann Mather; Timothy Richard Matthews; Rev. Colin C. McKechinie; Methodist Magazine, 1818 (various); James Montgomery; Rev. John Newton; Laurence Oliphant; Gideon Ouseley; George Osborn; Mary Ann Parkinson; and Thomas Parson.

Contents (continued from previous box): John Pawson; Thomas Payne; Christopher Peacock; M. Pendleton; Thomas Pendleton; John Prickard; Robert Raikes; Richard Rodda; Sarah Savage; Selina, Countess of Huntingdon; Rev. John Smith; William Smith; Sampson Staniforth; John Story; Rev. Thomas Stratten; J. S. Sutcliffe; William Taylor; Silas Told; Juan de Valides; Samuel Walker; Charles Wesley; John Wesley; Wesleyan-Methodist Magazine, 1877 (various); Rev. George Whitefield; William Williams; Duncan Wright; and Miscellaneous.
Approximately sixty book plates, the scrapbook pages from which they have loosened, and printed material on this topic.

scopecontent.p: Alphabetical index, circa 250 pages, of more than 600 18th-century preachers. Each entry lists preacher's stations in chronological order, followed by citations for the sources of this information. Undated but probably prepared in the late 1970s or 1980s, by Baker and Enid Hickingbotham (his daughter). Related material, including this index at other stages of its composition, can be found under "British Preachers' Stationing, 1744-1764" in the Wesley Works Archive, Methodist Societies Series, Minutes Subseries.

Subject Files Series: Wesley Family Files Subseries, 1692-1997 and undated

scopecontent.p: Family members are identified here by their relationship to JW (1703-1791) and/or Charles Wesley (1707-1788), cited as JW or CW, respectively. In addition to FB's correspondence, notes, and printed materials, many folders contain extensive transcriptions and photocopies of original manuscript letters, journals, and writings by Wesley family members. Original manuscript items and many 18th and 19th century engravings present in these folders are being transferred to the Frank Baker Collection of Wesleyana and British Methodism, in most cases to the Wesley Family Series. Separation sheets and, where feasible, photocopies of originals have been left in the folders in this subseries. Subseries is arranged by family member, chronologically by date of birth, with a concluding folder group of various topics.

scopecontent.p: Card files have been minimally identified and described, and arranged in three groups: Quotations and Concordances, Bicentennial Edition, Wesley's Library and Reading, and Other Cardfiles. Card counts are approximate, and total approximately 50,000 cards. The various files were numbered and original order has been maintained, with some changes to house like sizes together.

did.unittitle: Quotations used by John and/or Charles Wesley, undated

scopecontent.p: Four files indexing quotations used by John (or perhaps Charles, at times) Wesley. The first two boxes house two files for quotations used by JW, one for English and the other for foreign languages (usually Latin); both are organized alphabetically by topic or keyword. The third box houses two more files for sources of his quotations, arranged by author. A note at the beginning of the first file indicates that Baker thought he had indexed and cross-referenced about 800 quotations in all.

did.unittitle: Concordances to JW's works, 1970s-1985 and undated

scopecontent.p: Four files that somewhat complement the quotations indexes above, but also greatly expand into preparations for a general concordance. A note in the first box indicates that Baker inherited most of this unpublished work, Notes for a Wesley Concordance, from George Lawton in 1974. Lawton appears to have provided the first three indexes here, which Baker expanded at times. The first index is for aphorisms (Box 142, 250 entries). The second index is a general concordance (Boxes 142-146, 6500 entries). The third index is for proverbs and slang and colloquial expressions (Boxes 146-147, 1200 entries). Following this is a series on unlabeled cards that may be duplicates, then the concordances conclude with Baker's own index of Christian names in Wesley's writings (Box 147, 250 entries).
Separated materials: articles by George Lawton. See folder for these indexes housed in Subject Files, Card Files Information Folders.

did.unittitle: Bicentennial Edition card files and indexes

scopecontent.p: Large set of card files that are often related to volumes of the Bicentennial Edition of the Works of John Wesley, for which Frank Baker served as General Editor. Files have been slightly rearranged to reflect the sequence of volumes in the Works. These files often complement other documents to be found in the related collection, the Wesley Works Archive.

did.unittitle: Explanatory Notes upon the New Testament (Bicentennial Ed. Volumes 5-6)--alphabetical topic index, undated
The Methodist Societies: History, Nature, and Design (Bicentennial Ed. Vol. 9)--alphabetical by topic, undated

processinfo.p: Separated materials: printed index to Volume 9 housed in Subject Files, Card Files Information Folders.

did.unittitle: The Methodist Societies: Minutes of the Conference (Bicentennial Ed. Vol. 10), undated

scopecontent.p: Several indexes, mainly related to material that was excluded from the published volume. The first file, American Preachers (Boxes 149-150), provides the names and chronological outlines of the stationing of approximately 500 18th century Methodist preachers in the United States. Following this is a similar but much longer file for British preachers (Box 149), outlining the careers of some 1000 preachers. A keyword index to the Minutes, from 1744-1791, follows these files in Box 150; and the group concludes with a short name index of circuits in Britain. The last two files house approximately 800 and 100 entries, respectively.

did.unittitle: Theological writings, Pastoral writings, and Primitive Physic, undated

scopecontent.p:
Three alphabetical topic indexes for Doctrinal and Controversial Treatises,
Social/Political Tracts, and one portion of Medical Writings (Bicentennial Ed. Volumes 12, 14, and 17, respectively).

did.unittitle: Letters (Bicentennial Ed. Volumes 25-31) indexes and files, undated

scopecontent.p: Extensive card files that index the letters of JW in a variety of ways: chronological order; index to letters I-II; index to Letters III (in preparation as of 2011); non-Telford letters; and archival locations of Wesley letters worldwide. Baker's instructions from the first card of the extensive index of "non-Telford" letters (entries that did not appear in the previous standard version, by John Telford), give some idea of the value of this index of Wesley letters that have yet to appear in a scholarly edition: "Index, JW letters, 1756-1791. Separate card for each Name, Place, Subject. Include towns for recipients and towns from which JW wrote, but JW himself, nor recipient. List entries by date. List all names and places. List all theological subjects, scriptural quotations, historical themes, illnesses, etc...".

did.unittitle: Bibliography (Bicentennial Ed. Volumes 33-34) indexes and files, undated

scopecontent.p: Extensive card file bibliographies of Wesleyan and Methodist writing. There seem to be three bibliographies represented: one that may be preparatory for both the Bibliography volumes of the Bicentennial Edition and for editions of Baker's own A Union Catalogue of the Publications of John and Charles Wesley (3000 cards); one that is covers Methodist and Wesleyan literature and scholarship in general rather than just work by the Wesleys (12,000 cards); and one that may be a keyword index to the unpublished, partial draft of the Bibliography that Baker completed circa 1981 (700 cards). All are heavily annotated with descriptive and intellectual analysis. Card counts are approximate.

scopecontent.p: Baker retained copies of a number of his students' papers at Duke, with the intent that certain of them be included in the archive for the intended "Wesley Research Centre" he mentions over the years in his correspondence and other documents. Materials in this subseries comprise a portion of that student work. Several of the students represented here went on to become prominent Wesleyan and Methodist scholars in their own right, including Richard P. Heitzenrater, who succeeded Baker as General Editor of the Wesley Bicentennial Edition. The first folder in the subseries contains a 1991 memo by Baker in which he lists many of the students and papers gathered in this subseries. Arranged alphabetically by author's surname.

scopecontent.p: A large collection of research and production files for all of Frank Baker's writings, published and unpublished. A subseries for monographs is arranged by the bibliography numbers established by Elizabeth Hart in her volume on the works of Baker, also included in the first box of the subseries. Files contain correspondence; notes; clippings; printed material such as pamphlets, maps, histories, and reprints; publicity; drafts and proofs; and research for each of the works. Note that early dates often represent reproductions, not originals. A separate subseries houses the research files for Baker's thesis, later published in book form, on William Grimshaw, Methodist minister, and religion in 18th century England. Also includes a subseries of unpublished and unfinished works, and a subseries of writings by other individuals collected by or sent to Baker.

scopecontent.p: Extensive printouts of data derived from unpublished doctoral research Albin conducted at Cambridge University, circa 1978-1982. Compiles the texts and lists the archival sources of several hundred Methodist letters and autobiographies written between 1725 and 1790. The first ten folders contain the raw data; the final seven folders contain indexes of the material sorted by various criteria, such as author, date, and preachers' station. Albin made this research available to Baker to use in the late 1980s when he was serving as Textual Editor of the Wesley Bicentennial Edition.

processinfo.p: Folders numbered 1-9 to reflect the various sections and versions of the manuscript, but there are 17 folders in all, due to several notebooks being disbound into "A" and "B" folders.]

scopecontent.p: Typed manuscript. Includes photocopy of original cover. History covers about 40 pages; the rest, approx. 200 pages, consists of many one-page biographies of women in the Society, and a large number of newsletter extracts and photographs. "Written at the request of the Conference Historical Committee."

Five articles: Women: Susanna Wesley and Her Daughters, 1981, 1982; Horace Walpole and the Methodists, undated; John Wesley and the Press-Gangs, 1975; John Wesley's Daily Routine, 1974; and John Wesley's Mission to Scotland, 1751-1790, 1988.
